options.label: B
options.text: Turbulence

options.label: C
options.text: Gravity

options.label: D
options.text: Electromagnetism

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That it varies in proportion to the 5/3rds power of the length

options.label: C
options.text: That it remains constant regardless of the length

options.label: D
options.text: That it decreases exponentially with the length

options.label: A
options.text: That there is no pattern of turbulent fluid structures in his paintings

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: That his paintings from his period of psychotic agitation show no sign of turbulence

options.label: D
options.text: That his self-portrait with a pipe shows a strong correspondence to fluid turbulence

options.label: B

title: What causes antibiotic resistance? - Kevin Wu

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the number of bacterial cells and human cells in the human body?

options.label: B
options.text: There are an equal number of human cells and bacterial cells.

options.label: C
options.text: There are 10 times more bacterial cells than human cells.

options.label: D
options.text: There are 100 times more bacterial cells than human cells.

multiple-choice.question: How do antibiotics work to fight bacterial infections?

options.label: A
options.text: By destroying human cells to prevent the spread of infection.

options.label: B
options.text: By interrupting cell wall synthesis or interfering with vital processes in bacteria.

options.label: C
options.text: By boosting the immune system to fight off infections.

options.label: D
options.text: By neutralizing viruses that cause infections.

multiple-choice.question: Why are antibiotics becoming less effective in fighting bacterial infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the antibiotics themselves are becoming weaker over time.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the bacteria are developing resistance to the antibiotics through natural selection.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the human body is becoming more susceptible to infections.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the medical community is not using antibiotics correctly.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that bacteria can share their genes with other bacteria?

options.label: A
options.text: Through reproduction.

options.label: B
options.text: Through conjugation, where they connect through pili to share genes.

options.label: C
options.text: Through mutation, where they randomly change their genes.

options.label: D
options.text: Through genetic drift, where their genes change over time.

multiple-choice.question: What is one strategy being explored to combat the rise of super bacteria?

options.label: A
options.text: Developing stronger antibiotics to fight off the super bacteria.

options.label: B
options.text: Using vaccines to prevent infections from occurring in the first place.

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing the use of antibiotics to try and wipe out the super bacteria.

options.label: D
options.text: Focusing on treating viral infections instead of bacterial infections.

title: How quantum mechanics explains global warming - Lieven Scheire

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The energy levels increase.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What makes tattoos permanent? - Claudia Aguirre

multiple-choice.question: How many skin cells do humans shed per day?
What is the main reason why tattoos do not flake off along with the skin cells that are shed?

options.label: A
options.text: The tattoo ink is inserted into the epidermis, the outermost layer of skin.

options.label: B
options.text: The tattoo ink is inserted deeper into the skin than the outermost layer that gets shed.

options.label: C
options.text: The tattoo ink is made of a special material that is resistant to shedding.

options.label: D
options.text: The tattoo ink is applied in a way that makes it stick to the skin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of macrophages in the process of making tattoos permanent?

options.label: A
options.text: They eat the invading material and carry it away from the skin.

options.label: B
options.text: They produce collagen fibers that help to heal the skin.

options.label: C
options.text: They engulf the ink particles and make them visible through the skin.

options.label: D
options.text: They stimulate the immune system to respond to the tattoo ink.

multiple-choice.question: Why do tattoos fade naturally over time?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the dermal cells that contain the ink die and are replaced by new cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the immune system's macrophages break down the ink particles and carry them away.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the skin sheds its outermost layer, taking the tattoo ink with it.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the tattoo ink is made of a material that degrades over time.

multiple-choice.question: How are tattoos typically removed?

options.label: A
options.text: By surgically removing the skin that contains the tattoo.

options.label: B
options.text: By using a laser to break apart the underlying pigment colors.

options.label: C
options.text: By applying a special cream that dissolves the tattoo ink.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a combination of these methods.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: A comprehensive understanding of the artist's intentions.

title: How to choose your news - Damon Brown

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the major differences between the current media landscape and the one that existed a few decades ago?

options.label: A
options.text: There are fewer sources of information available today.

options.label: B
options.text: The news is delivered at the same reliable time every evening.

options.label: C
options.text: There are many more sources of information available today.

options.label: D
options.text: The news is only delivered through print media.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the problems with relying on social media for news?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows rumors to spread before they can be verified.

options.label: B
options.text: It only provides access to mainstream news sources.

options.label: C
options.text: It is too slow to provide updates on current events.

options.label: D
options.text: It is too expensive to access.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to separate fact from opinion when consuming news?

options.label: A
options.text: Because opinions are always more interesting than facts.

options.label: B
options.text: Because facts are always more accurate than opinions.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it helps to identify biases and potential inaccuracies.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not important to separate fact from opinion.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to verify the accuracy of a news report?

options.label: A
options.text: By only reading news from one source.

options.label: B
options.text: By relying on anonymous sources.

options.label: C
options.text: By doing a web search to find additional information or context.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring any reports that contradict your own opinions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the responsibility that comes with the freedom to access a wide range of news sources?

options.label: A
options.text: The responsibility to only read news from one source.

options.label: B
options.text: The responsibility to curate our own experience and ensure that the flow of information does not become overwhelming.

options.label: C
options.text: The responsibility to ignore any reports that contradict our own opinions.

options.label: D
options.text: The responsibility to only rely on social media for news.
